intro: Brassica juncea var. aspera, commonly known as rough mustard, is an annual plant native to temperate regions of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its cross-shaped flowers and glucosinolate compounds. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with hairy stems and serrated leaves. Its small, yellow flowers develop into pods containing several seeds, which are used in traditional medicine and as a spice. This variety is valued for its nutritional content and adaptability to various soil conditions.
